extractions.description: This research paper addresses the intersection of fairness and privacy in item rankings. In particular, it explores methods to achieve item fairness while preserving user privacy using differential privacy and secure multi-party computation. The paper evaluates the approach's impact on privacy, fairness, and ranking quality using real-world datasets.

type.justification: The paper includes experimental results using real-world datasets.
type.quote: We demonstrate the applicability of our proposed solution by experimenting on three real-world datasets.

name.justification: The research focuses on ranking systems and their fairness and privacy implications, a primary concern within Information Retrieval.
name.quote: Users worldwide access massive amounts of curated data in the form of rankings on a daily basis. The societal impact of this ease of access has been studied and work has been done to propose and enforce various notions of fairness in rankings.

name.justification: The main contribution involves privacy-preserving techniques like differential privacy and secure multi-party computation.
name.quote: specifically, differential privacy and secure multi-party computation.

name.justification: The research focuses on achieving fairness in item rankings.
name.quote: Our work extends the equity of amortized attention ranking mechanism to be privacy-preserving, and we evaluate its effects with respect to privacy, fairness, and ranking quality.

name.quote: We use three recommender system datasets in our experiments: Amazon Digital Music, Book Crossing, and MovieLens-1M.
